Novels

Novels.Rmd
library(corpuscleaner)
library(dplyr)
library(tidytext)
library(magrittr)
library(topicmodels)
library(stringr)
library(tidyr)
library(reshape2)

Understanding corpuscleaner

The corpuscleaner package has a tibble called novels() which consists of 18 cleaned documents usable for basic text analysis.

novels() %>%
  unnest_tokens(word, 
                text, 
                token = "words") %>%
  anti_join(get_stopwords("en", source = "smart"))
#> # A tibble: 895,673 × 5
#>    title                year author         novel_bookshelf word     
#>    <chr>               <dbl> <chr>          <chr>           <chr>    
#>  1 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  monk     
#>  2 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  romance  
#>  3 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  matthew  
#>  4 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  lewis    
#>  5 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  somnia   
#>  6 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  terrores 
#>  7 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  magicos  
#>  8 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  miracula 
#>  9 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  sagas    
#> 10 The Monk: A Romance  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction  nocturnos
#> # ℹ 895,663 more rows

It also includes a function called polish which minimizes using the entire novels() tibble for text analysis, and instead pick the document of your choice and column names, such as the year the novel was published, the author of the novel, or both.

corpuscleaner::novels_tgt
#> # A tibble: 369,611 × 5
#>    title               text                year author         novel_bookshelf
#>    <chr>               <chr>              <dbl> <chr>          <chr>          
#>  1 The Monk: A Romance THE MONK A ROMANCE  1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  2 The Monk: A Romance by MATTHEW LEWIS    1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  3 The Monk: A Romance Somnia              1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  4 The Monk: A Romance terrores magicos    1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  5 The Monk: A Romance miracula            1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  6 The Monk: A Romance sagas               1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  7 The Monk: A Romance Nocturnos lemures   1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  8 The Monk: A Romance portentaque         1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#>  9 The Monk: A Romance Horat               1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#> 10 The Monk: A Romance Dreams              1795 Lewis, Matthew Gothic Fiction 
#> # ℹ 369,601 more rows
polish(title == "Wuthering Heights", vars = c("year", "author"))
#> # A tibble: 20,721 × 4
#> # Groups:   title, text [17,401]
#>    title             text                                            year author
#>    <chr>             <chr>                                          <dbl> <chr>

#>  2 Wuthering Heights CHAPTER I                                       1847 Bront…
#>  3 Wuthering Heights I have just returned from a visit to my landl…  1847 Bront…
#>  4 Wuthering Heights This is certainly a beautiful country           1847 Bront…
#>  5 Wuthering Heights In all England                                  1847 Bront…
#>  6 Wuthering Heights I do not believe that I could have fixed on a…  1847 Bront…
#>  7 Wuthering Heights A perfect misanthropist s heaven                1847 Bront…
#>  8 Wuthering Heights and Mr                                          1847 Bront…
#>  9 Wuthering Heights Heathcliff and I are such a suitable pair to …  1847 Bront…
#> 10 Wuthering Heights A capital fellow                                1847 Bront…
#> # ℹ 20,711 more rows

Usage in Text Analysis

Aside from this, you can do higher corpus analysis such as tf-idf:

# Using novels() to do tf-idf
# Part 1: Finding the commonly used words in all documents
doc_words = novels() %>%
  unnest_tokens(word, text) %>%
  count(title, word, sort = T)

tot_words = doc_words %>%
  group_by(title) %>% 
  summarize(total = sum(n))

put_words = left_join(doc_words, tot_words)
put_words
#> # A tibble: 150,525 × 4
#>    title                    word      n  total
#>    <chr>                    <chr> <int>  <int>
#>  1 The Mysteries of Udolpho the   19063 294093
#>  2 The Woman in White       the   14947 250487
#>  3 Ivanhoe                  the   12464 179284
#>  4 The Mysteries of Udolpho and    9818 294093
#>  5 The Mysteries of Udolpho to     9693 294093
#>  6 The Mysteries of Udolpho of     9523 294093
#>  7 The Woman in White       to     8486 250487
#>  8 Great Expectations       the    8145 188943
#>  9 The Portrait of a Lady   the    8066 233165
#> 10 Dracula                  the    7865 161799
#> # ℹ 150,515 more rows

# Part 2: Using Zipf's law in Finding Word Frequency
frequency_rank = put_words %>%
                    group_by(title) %>%
                    mutate(rank = row_number(),
                           term_frequency = n/total) %>%
                    ungroup()

frequency_rank
#> # A tibble: 150,525 × 6
#>    title                    word      n  total  rank term_frequency
#>    <chr>                    <chr> <int>  <int> <int>          <dbl>
#>  1 The Mysteries of Udolpho the   19063 294093     1         0.0648
#>  2 The Woman in White       the   14947 250487     1         0.0597
#>  3 Ivanhoe                  the   12464 179284     1         0.0695
#>  4 The Mysteries of Udolpho and    9818 294093     2         0.0334
#>  5 The Mysteries of Udolpho to     9693 294093     3         0.0330
#>  6 The Mysteries of Udolpho of     9523 294093     4         0.0324
#>  7 The Woman in White       to     8486 250487     2         0.0339
#>  8 Great Expectations       the    8145 188943     1         0.0431
#>  9 The Portrait of a Lady   the    8066 233165     1         0.0346
#> 10 Dracula                  the    7865 161799     1         0.0486
#> # ℹ 150,515 more rows

Or do some Topic Modeling:

# Using novels to do some Topic Modeling
# Part 1: Find the books you want to use in Topic Modeling 
# Search for Novels that have CHAPTER I... In Them 
novels() %>%
  filter(str_detect(text, "^CHAPTER ")) %>%
  select(title, text)
#> # A tibble: 293 × 2
#>    title               text                                                     
#>    <chr>               <chr>                                                    
#>  1 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER I                                                
#>  2 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER II Forse se tu gustassi una sol volta            
#>  3 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER III                                              
#>  4 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER I Avaunt                                         
#>  5 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER II O You                                         
#>  6 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER III While in each other s arms entranced They lay
#>  7 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER IV                                               
#>  8 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER I The crickets sing                              
#>  9 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER II Tell us                                       
#> 10 The Monk: A Romance CHAPTER III Oh                                           
#> # ℹ 283 more rows

# Optional: 
# novels() %>%
#   filter(str_detect(text, "^CHAPTER ")) %>%
#   select(title, text) %>%
#   print(n = 250)

book_titles = c("Frankenstein", "Ivanhoe", "The Portrait of a Lady", "Wuthering Heights")

books = novels() %>%
  filter(title %in% book_titles)

# Diving these books by chapter 
book_chapters = books %>%
  group_by(title) %>%
  mutate(chapter = cumsum(str_detect(text, "^CHAPTER "))) %>%
  filter(chapter > 0) %>%
  unite(document, title, chapter)

book_words = book_chapters %>%
  unnest_tokens(word, text) 

book_wordcounts = book_words %>%
  anti_join(get_stopwords("en", source = "smart")) %>%
  count(document, word, sort = T)

book_wordcounts
#> # A tibble: 140,505 × 3
#>    document                  word       n
#>    <chr>                     <chr>  <int>
#>  1 Ivanhoe_27                thou      75
#>  2 The Portrait of a Lady_19 isabel    69
#>  3 Ivanhoe_40                knight    66
#>  4 Ivanhoe_27                de        61
#>  5 The Portrait of a Lady_40 isabel    61
#>  6 Ivanhoe_39                thou      60
#>  7 The Portrait of a Lady_51 isabel    57
#>  8 Ivanhoe_33                thou      55
#>  9 Ivanhoe_33                prior     53
#> 10 The Portrait of a Lady_52 isabel    53
#> # ℹ 140,495 more rows

# Part 2: Convert to LDA for Topic Modeling
book_chapter_DTM = book_wordcounts %>%
                            cast_dtm(document, word, n)

book_chapter_DTM
#> <<DocumentTermMatrix (documents: 157, terms: 19685)>>
#> Non-/sparse entries: 140505/2950040
#> Sparsity           : 95%
#> Maximal term length: 18
#> Weighting          : term frequency (tf)

# Use LDA in Four Topic Modeling given we have Four Documents
book_chapter_LDA = LDA(book_chapter_DTM, k = 4, control = list(seed = 1234))
book_chapter_LDA
#> A LDA_VEM topic model with 4 topics.

# Finally, examine a per topic per word probabilities 
book_topics = tidy(book_chapter_LDA, matrix = "beta")
book_topics
#> # A tibble: 78,740 × 3
#>    topic term        beta
#>    <int> <chr>      <dbl>
#>  1     1 thou   2.16e-  4
#>  2     2 thou   3.70e-  4
#>  3     3 thou   6.10e-172
#>  4     4 thou   1.26e-  2
#>  5     1 isabel 2.07e- 11
#>  6     2 isabel 5.23e- 21
#>  7     3 isabel 1.93e-  2
#>  8     4 isabel 9.50e-208
#>  9     1 knight 3.88e- 22
#> 10     2 knight 4.70e- 36
#> # ℹ 78,730 more rows

Therefore, this package is useful in higher or basic Corpus Analysis.
